title: Engine Management System

body.body: This model is fitted with an electronic engine management system which encompasses control of both ignition and fuel delivery. The engine electronic control module (ECM) draws information from sensors positioned around the engine, cooling and air intake systems and precisely calculates ignition advance and fueling requirements for all engine speeds and loads.
In addition, the system has an on-board diagnostic function. For additional information, see

- situated on the rear of the airbox plenum. As the density of the air changes with temperature (therefore the amount of oxygen available to ignite the fuel), an intake air temperature sensor is fitted. Changes in air temperature are compensated for by adjusting the amount of fuel injected to a level consistent with clean combustion and low emissions.

- situated on the on the engine electronic control module bracket under the rider's seat. The ambient air pressure sensor measures atmospheric air pressure. With this information, the amount of fuel per injection is adjusted to suit the prevailing conditions.

- situated behind the airbox plenum, top right hand side, and is connected to each of the three throttle bodies by equal length tubes. The MAP sensor provides information to the engine ECM which is used at shallow throttle angles (very small throttle openings) to provide accurate engine load indications to the ECM. This degree of engine load accuracy allows the ECM to make very small adjustments to fuel and ignition which would otherwise not be possible from throttle angle data alone.
- situated on the clutch lever. The clutch must be pulled in for the starter motor to operate.

- situated in the alternator cover. The crankshaft position sensor detects movement of teeth attached to the alternator rotor. The teeth give a reference point from which the actual crankshaft position is calculated. The crankshaft position sensor information is used by the engine ECM to determine engine speed and crankshaft position in relation to the point where fuel is injected and ignition of the fuel occurs.

- situated at the front of the cylinder head in the thermostat housing. Coolant temperature information, received by the engine ECM, is used to optimise fueling at all engine temperatures and to calculate hot and cold start fueling requirements.

- situated in the front end on the left hand side of the catalytic converter assembly. The oxygen sensor constantly relays information to the engine ECM on the content of the exhaust gases. When the data is viewed the voltage signal will oscillate rapidly, indicating the engine control module is making rapid adjustments to the air/fuel ratio.
- situated at the top of the side stand leg. If the side stand is in the down position, the engine will not run unless the transmission is in neutral.

- situated in the twist grip housing. The twist grip position sensor is used to relay twist grip position information to the engine ECM. The engine ECM uses this information to drive the throttle actuation motor to the correct position.
- situated on the left hand side of the throttle bodies. The throttle position sensor is used to relay throttle position information to the engine ECM.

- situated in the upper crankcase near the starter motor. The gear position sensor provides the engine ECM with selected gear information. This is used to prevent the engine from starting if the transmission is in gear. The TFT instruments will show the selected gear.

- situated on the gear change linkage. Triumph Shift Assist adjusts the engine torque to allow gears to engage, without closure of the throttle twist grip or operation of the clutch. This feature works for both up shifts and down shifts of gear. The clutch must be used for stopping and pulling away.
